newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish NFI Foksal '96 loss narrows to PLN 20.9 mln.
newsitem.headline: Polish NFI Foksal '96 loss narrows to PLN 20.9 mln.

text.p: The net loss of Foksal National Investment Fund (NFI No. 10) in Poland's mass privatisation scheme fell to 20.9 million zlotys last year from 28.1 million in 1995, the fund said in an issue prospectus.
The fund said it planned to float shares of chemical company ZM Ropczyce SA in 1997 and two or three others later.
Chemical companies made up 52.3 percent of the fund's portfolio and this high concentration was considered as one of the risk factors, the prospectus said.
The fund also said it was negotiating with investors to take stakes in three firms of its portfolio.
The fund said it wanted to invest in companies which had annual sales of at least 40 million zlotys and recorded a profit margin of at least five percent.
Under the government's NFI programme, shares in about 500 mid-sized companies are allocated to 15 NFIs run by foreign and domestic management firms.

From May 12 the 26 million Poles who bought a participation unit in the scheme will have the opportunity to exchange it for 15 shares, one in each fund, which are expected to start trade on the Warsaw bourse around mid-year.
Each NFI has 31,026,185 shares. The units lose their validity on December 31, 1998.
